title: EPIC: NTM Tracker - Complete Implementation
description:
## Overview
NTM Tracker is a Windows system tray application that monitors NTM (Named Tmux Manager) sessions running in WSL2, providing real-time session/pane status, compact events, escalations, and usage analytics.

## Project Goals
1. **Real-time Visibility**: Surface what coding agents are doing across multiple tmux sessions
2. **Compact Detection**: Know when AI agents auto-compact their context (potential loss of work state)
3. **Escalation Alerts**: Get notified when agents need human input (confirmations, errors)
4. **Usage Analytics**: Track token estimates, active time, compacts per session/day
5. **Low Friction**: System tray stays out of the way; dashboard when you need depth

## Architecture Summary
- **WSL Daemon**: Rust binary (tokio + rusqlite) - single deployable artifact
- **Windows App**: Tauri 2.0 + Svelte 5 - ~5MB bundle, native tray
- **IPC**: stdio JSON-RPC (default), optional WebSocket/HTTP
- **Data**: SQLite with WAL, in-memory cache for hot paths

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Daemon reliably tracks sessions/panes with <1% CPU idle overhead
- [ ] Compact detection catches >90% of Claude Code auto-compacts
- [ ] End-to-end update latency p95 < 500ms
- [ ] Windows app starts in <3s, uses <50MB RAM
- [ ] Works on Windows 10/11 with WSL2 (systemd optional)

## Key Documents
- PLAN.md: Full technical specification
- AGENTS.md: Agent workflow rules
- README.md: User-facing documentation

## Risk Areas (addressed in Phase -1)
- WSL localhost networking can be flaky → stdio default
- NTM/tmux command latency varies wildly → explicit timeouts
- Sensitive output in agent sessions → capture off by default

title: EPIC: Phase -1 - Risk Spikes & Validation
description:
## Purpose
Validate the two biggest unknowns BEFORE committing to feature work. This phase de-risks the entire project.

## Why This Phase Exists
The plan makes assumptions about:
1. NTM robot outputs being available and stable
2. tmux metadata polling being cheap enough
3. WSL localhost connectivity being reliable
4. Command latency being predictable

If any of these assumptions are wrong, the architecture needs to change. Better to discover that now.

## Key Deliverables
1. **Transport Decision**: One chosen default (stdio) + one tested fallback
2. **Performance Baseline**: Measured CPU + command latency distribution (p50/p95/p99)
3. **Fixture Corpus**: Real session data for parser/detector golden tests
4. **Fuzz Harness**: Parser resilience against malformed input

## Exit Criteria
- [ ] stdio real-time push validated without relying on WSL localhost forwarding
- [ ] Command latency measured: tmux < 2s p99, ntm < 10s p99
- [ ] CPU baseline: <1% on 20 sessions × 6 panes
- [ ] Fixture corpus committed with at least 10 diverse session samples
- [ ] Parser fuzz harness passes 10k iterations without panic

## Technical Context
The daemon will spawn external processes (tmux, ntm, wsl.exe) frequently. These are the main failure modes:
- Hung processes blocking the async runtime
- Inconsistent output formats across versions
- WSL networking flakiness (localhost:port not forwarding)

This phase surfaces these problems before we've built features on top.

## Dependencies
None - this is the foundation

title: EPIC: Phase 0 - Install & Versioning
description:
## Purpose
Establish deterministic daemon install, protocol negotiation, and safe upgrade path BEFORE building features.

## Why This Phase Exists
Multi-component systems fail at boundaries. If the Windows app and WSL daemon have version mismatches, the user gets cryptic errors. This phase ensures:
1. First-run bootstrap works reliably
2. Version handshakes prevent incompatible pairings
3. Upgrades are atomic and reversible

## Key Deliverables
1. **Bootstrap Flow**: Windows app installs daemon into WSL (no manual steps)
2. **Version Handshake**: UI refuses to operate on incompatible protocol/schema
3. **Upgrade Path**: Daemon can be updated atomically by the app
4. **Rollback**: Previous daemon binary kept for quick recovery

## Technical Approach
- Daemon is a single static Rust binary (~5MB)
- Windows app embeds the binary or downloads on first run
- Protocol version in hello handshake
- Schema version in SQLite meta table
- Keep N-1 binary for rollback

## Exit Criteria
- [ ] Fresh Windows install → daemon running in <30s
- [ ] Version mismatch → clear error message, not silent failure
- [ ] Upgrade → atomic replace + restart
- [ ] Rollback → one-click recovery to previous version

## Dependencies
Depends on Phase -1 (risk spikes) to validate transport choice

title: Implement first-run daemon bootstrap
description:
Purpose: Implement first-run bootstrap so Windows app installs daemon into WSL without manual steps.

Background:
Users should not need to manually install anything in WSL. The Windows app should handle:
1. Detecting if daemon is installed
2. Installing/updating the daemon binary
3. Creating required directories and config files

Implementation Approach:
1. Embed daemon binary in Windows installer OR download on first run
2. Use wsl.exe to copy binary to ~/.local/bin/ntm-tracker-daemon
3. Create ~/.config/ntm-tracker/ with default config
4. Create ~/.local/share/ntm-tracker/ for data
5. Verify installation with health check

Edge Cases:
- Multiple WSL distros: prompt user to select or use default
- Permission issues: clear error messages
- Existing installation: upgrade flow

Acceptance Criteria:
- [ ] Fresh install completes in < 30 seconds
- [ ] No manual WSL commands required
- [ ] Installation verified before proceeding

title: Implement version handshake protocol
description:
Purpose: Implement version handshake so UI refuses to operate on incompatible protocol/schema versions.

Background:
Version mismatches between Windows app and WSL daemon cause cryptic errors. Better to fail fast with a clear message.

Protocol:
1. Daemon sends hello notification on connect with:
   - protocolVersion: JSON-RPC schema version
   - schemaVersion: SQLite schema version
   - daemonVersion: Daemon build version
   - capabilities: Feature flags
2. Client checks compatibility:
   - protocolVersion must match exactly (or be in supported range)
   - schemaVersion mismatch triggers migration or error
   - capabilities used for feature detection

Version Compatibility Matrix:
- Same major version: compatible
- Different major version: incompatible
- Schema upgrades: handled by daemon migrations

Error Handling:
- Clear message: "Daemon version X is incompatible with app version Y"
- Offer to upgrade daemon if possible
- Link to troubleshooting docs

Acceptance Criteria:
- [ ] hello notification includes version info
- [ ] Client validates on connect
- [ ] Clear error on mismatch

Files: daemon/src/rpc.rs, app/src-tauri/src/daemon.rs, shared/schema/version.json

title: Implement daemon upgrade path
description:
Purpose: Enable daemon updates from the Windows app (atomic replace + restart).

Background:
Users should not need to manually update the daemon. The app should:
1. Detect when a newer daemon is available
2. Download/extract new binary
3. Stop running daemon gracefully
4. Replace binary atomically
5. Restart daemon

Implementation:
1. Store daemon version in app config
2. Compare with embedded/downloaded version on startup
3. Use atomic rename for replacement (daemon.new -> daemon)
4. Signal daemon to shutdown via RPC (daemon.shutdown method)
5. Wait for clean exit, then start new version

Rollback:
- Keep previous binary as daemon.backup
- If new daemon fails health check, restore backup

Acceptance Criteria:
- [ ] Upgrade detection works
- [ ] Atomic replacement without data loss
- [ ] Rollback on failure

Files: app/src-tauri/src/upgrade.rs, daemon/src/shutdown.rs

title: Implement daemon rollback mechanism
description:
Purpose: Keep previous daemon binary for quick recovery from failed upgrades.

Background:
If a daemon upgrade goes wrong (crashes on startup, incompatible with data), users need a way to recover quickly without manual intervention.

Implementation:
1. Before upgrade, copy current binary to daemon.backup
2. After upgrade, run health check within 10 seconds
3. If health check fails:
   - Stop new daemon
   - Restore daemon.backup to daemon
   - Start restored daemon
   - Log upgrade failure for diagnostics
4. Keep only one backup (N-1 version)

User Experience:
- Automatic recovery is silent unless it fails
- If auto-recovery fails, show clear error with manual steps
- Diagnostics bundle includes upgrade attempt logs

Acceptance Criteria:
- [ ] Backup created before upgrade
- [ ] Auto-rollback on health check failure
- [ ] Manual rollback documented

title: EPIC: Phase 1 - Foundation (Daemon)
description:
## Purpose
Build the working WSL daemon with data collection, detection, and API - the core engine of NTM Tracker.

## Scope
This phase delivers a fully functional daemon that:
1. Polls tmux/ntm and tracks session/pane state
2. Detects compacts, escalations, status changes
3. Persists data to SQLite with proper schema
4. Exposes JSON-RPC API over stdio (default) + optional WS/HTTP
5. Has comprehensive tests including golden tests

## Architecture
```
daemon/
├── src/
│   ├── main.rs        # Entry point, CLI, signal handling
│   ├── rpc.rs         # JSON-RPC handlers + transport adapters
│   ├── collector.rs   # tmux + ntm polling loops
│   ├── detector.rs    # Compact/escalation/status detection
│   ├── db.rs          # SQLite schema + migrations + queries
│   ├── types.rs       # Shared types (ideally generated from schema)
│   └── command.rs     # CommandRunner with timeouts/budgets
└── Cargo.toml
```

## Key Design Decisions
1. **Single binary**: No runtime dependencies (Rust + static linking)
2. **stdio first**: JSON-RPC over stdin/stdout avoids WSL networking issues
3. **Adaptive polling**: Fast tmux metadata (1-2s), slower ntm reconcile (10-60s)
4. **Circuit breaker**: Back off on repeated failures, surface degraded state
5. **Single writer**: SQLite writes through one actor to avoid lock contention

## Exit Criteria
- [ ] Daemon starts and tracks sessions within 5s
- [ ] Compact detection works with >90% recall on test corpus
- [ ] API responds to health/sessions/events/stats methods
- [ ] Golden tests cover all parsers and detectors
- [ ] Integration test runs against real tmux

## Dependencies
- Phase -1 (risk spikes) must complete first
- Phase 0 (install) can proceed in parallel for bootstrap design

## Files
- daemon/src/*.rs
- daemon/Cargo.toml
- daemon/tests/
- shared/schema/

title: Implement compact detection algorithm
description:
Purpose: Implement compact detection from PLAN.md section 4.1.

Background:
Compacts occur when AI agents reset their context. We detect via:
1. Pattern matching on output (hard signals)
2. NTM counter changes (if available)
3. Context size drops (heuristic)

Hard Patterns (emit compact event):
- /Auto-compacting conversation/i
- /Conversation compacted/i
- /Context limit reached/i
- /\bcompacting\b/i
- /\bcontext\b.*\breset\b/i
- /\bstarting\s+fresh\s+context\b/i

Warning Patterns (optional, lower confidence):
- /approaching context limit/i
- /\bcontext\b.*\b(nearing|close to)\b.*\blimit\b/i

Detection Logic:
1. Strip ANSI from input
2. Match against patterns with debounce (60s)
3. Check NTM compact counter if available
4. Check context size drop (>75% drop of >20k tokens)

Event Output:
- type: compact
- trigger: auto | manual | error
- contextBefore: estimated tokens
- confidence: 0.0-1.0
- payload: detector name, raw match

Acceptance Criteria:

description:
Purpose: Implement pane status detection from PLAN.md section 4.3.

Background:
Pane status helps users know which agents are active, waiting for input, or idle. We combine tmux metadata with output pattern matching.

Status Values:
- active: Recent activity, processing patterns
- waiting: Prompt patterns, waiting for input
- idle: No activity for threshold
- ended: Pane dead or session ended

Primary Signal: tmux metadata
- pane_last_activity: Time of last activity
- pane_dead: Pane process exited
- pane_current_command: Running process

Secondary Signal: Output patterns (when captured)
Waiting patterns:
- /waiting for input/i
- /\(y\/n\)/i
- /press enter/i
- />\s*$/

Active patterns:
- /thinking\.\.\./i
- /processing/i
- /reading.*file/i
- /executing/i

Logic:
1. If pane_dead, status = ended
2. If waiting pattern AND recent activity, status = waiting
3. If active pattern, status = active
4. If no activity > threshold, status = idle
5. Default: status = active (if recent activity)

Acceptance Criteria:
- [ ] tmux metadata primary signal
- [ ] Pattern matching secondary signal
- [ ] Idle threshold configurable
- [ ] Status transitions logged

Purpose: Implement real-time updates via subscribe over active transport.

Background:

3. Process events, update stores
4. Handle reconnection and event replay

Channels:
- sessions: Session state changes
- events: Compact/escalation events
- stats: Periodic stats updates

Event Handling:
// Listen for daemon events
await listen('daemon-event', (event) => {
  const { method, params } = event.payload;
  switch (method) {
    case 'session.delta':
      updateSession(params);
      break;
    case 'events':
      appendEvents(params.events);
      break;
  }
});

Reconnection:
- Track lastEventId
- On reconnect, subscribe with sinceEventId
- Fetch missed events if gap detected

Error Handling:
- STALE_CURSOR: Full resync
- Connection lost: Show disconnected state
- Event processing error: Log, continue
